text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has made it its policy to engage in economic warfare against the
			 United States.

The CCP uses the resources of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) and the Chinese State to drain the
			 United States of economic might, including by means of economic espionage
			 and cyber espionage, unfair trade practices, unfair labor practices, and
			 currency manipulation.

Chinese state-owned enterprises (SOE) and the PLA are the main beneficiary of the CCP’s campaign of
			 theft against the United States.

Although many SOEs are listed on stock exchanges or officially privatized, the Chinese government
			 retains at least one-half of equity in those companies.

SOEs come under the control of the ministerial-level State-owned Assets Supervision and
			 Administration Commission.

Members of the boards of directors and senior management of SOEs are appointed by the State-owned
			 Assets Supervision and Administration Commission in consultation with the
			 Communist Party’s Department of Organization.

More than two-thirds of board members and three-quarters of senior executives of SOEs are either
			 Communist Party members or officials.
Corruption within the CCP is widespread and endemic.

CCP officials use their positions of control and influence within and over SOE’s to enrich
			 themselves and their families.
The vast majority of the Chinese people do not benefit from the corruption of the CCP.

Chinese SOEs are reported to have benefitted directly from their actions, including the State
			 Nuclear Power Technology Corporation, the Baosteel Group, and the Aluminum
			 Corporation of China (Chinalco).

The chairman of the board and the majority of the boards for the State Nuclear Power Technology
			 Corporation, the Baosteel Group, and the Aluminum Corporation of China
			 (Chinalco) are members of the CCP.

On May 21, 2014, Assistant Attorney General John Carlin said that criminal charges can justify
			 economic sanctions.

The indictment named members of Unit 61398 which is publicly identified as a Shanghai-based cyber
			 unit of the PLA also known as APT1.
Unit 61398 is part of the 2nd Bureau of the PLA, 3rd Department of the General Staff.

Unit 61398 was first publically identified in 2013 as APT1 by Mandiant, a United States cyber
			 security firm and leader in cyber incident response industry.

Mandiant exposed a timeline of Unit 61398’s economic espionage conducted since 2006 against 141
			 victims across multiple industries.

Mandiant’s conclusions have been supported by CrowdStrike, another cyber security company, which
			 publicly revealed the existence of Unit 61486, a related PLA unit
			 dedicated to cyber espionage.
